bioghist.p: John Beverley Nichols (1898-1983), was an English writer, playwright, actor, novelist and composer. He went to school at Marlborough College, and went to Balliol College, Oxford University, and was President of the Oxford Union and editor of Isis. Between his first novel, Prelude, published in 1920, and Twilight in 1982, he wrote more than 60 works, including six novels, five detective mysteries, four children's stories, six plays, and no fewer than six autobiographies. Nichols's long-term partner was Cyril Butcher.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Beverley Nichols. Materials include: correspondence; scrapbooks; diaries; drafts of books; published volumes; illustrations for the book Merry Hall; manuscript and photostatic musical scores; appointment books; and drawings and photographs, including images of Nichols's house in Glatton, Cambridgeshire. Of note is a scrapbook kept by a fan of Nichols, which documents the writer's career through photographs, letters, and newspaper clippings.
